diabetes, football and omnipod

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎07-02-2013 04:56 PM

My son was diagnosed with type 1 diabeties in May 2010 when he was 9 years old.   He has used the omnipod since January 2011.  We love the freedom and control the tubeless pump gives him.   However, we are facing a new set of circumstances with our pump this year as he enters 7th grade.  He has always been very active and plays many different organized sports.  While basketball and baseball have never given us any trouble with the omnipod, football has.  In the past, he has just played youth league football and the practices were just twice a week.  He would often knock off the pod during practice or a game, but since it wasn't everyday, it wasn't that big of a deal.  As he goes to junior high football this fall, he will have practice every day.  We are considering going off of the omnipod and back onto shots for football season.  I would like to hear from other parents who have children that have played football with the omnipod and find out what the experience was like.  

Report Inappropriate Content

Re: diabetes, football and omnipod

Options

‎07-03-2013 12:06 PM

Hi

I hope your son has a great football season.  My son, now 18, did not play football but did play basketball,run track and Varsity Golf with the medtronic pump with tubing.  Check with your diabetes team, but from what I remember, he checked blood sugar b4 practice or game, bolused for half the basal he would miss while pump was disconnected, ate a snack with no bolus, and did game/practice disconnected.  He also drank gatorade while disconnected.  He has run into trouble after practice going low several hours later.  CDE suggested 50% basal rate for a few hours after sport.  Even now, he has to be careful when he works out.  He disconnects and drinks gatorade without covering the carbs.  He also disconnected for pe in high school.  Again, check with your endo team or cde as I am pretty removed from the day to day management of diabetes any more.  They grow up and that does happen. I would not give up the pump if possible.  Junior high is such a changing time and the pump gives kids the freedom to eat when they want (which is all the time for growing boys) and fit in.  Do not be surprised it he eats 4-5 meals a day.  They are hungry and burning through food with all the activity.  Take care and let us know how it goes.

 

G 18 diagnosed 3/22/08

‎07-13-2013 11:05 AM

My daughter is in the process if getting an omnipod. We were told, several times, to call them if she had any issues with sports and it falling off. They promised her they can make it work for any sport, give your rep a call before you stop using it!

Re: diabetes, football and omnipod

Options

‎07-15-2013 05:15 PM

My daughter has worn her Omnipod for soccer, swimming, softball and basketball. We use Opsite flexifix tape when we need extra support.  It's a clear plastic, very thin, tape.( Think of sticky saran wrap.) I get the 4 inch wide roll and cut it into 7 strips 4 boxes wide. I place a strip on each of the 4 sides, directly on top of the adhesive it comes with. the other 3 strips I place across the body of the pod. This works well for us. I tried using a single large piece of the tape put this didn't work well for us. Also we use the Bands 4 Life arm band when it's on her arm. They make versions for the stomach and thigh too.  It's a swimsuit like material sewn into a band which you place over the pod. This has worked very well as my daughter does not like to put the tape on her arms ( pulls the hair there).. My dry cleaner tailor lady thought she could make some for us too, so if someone you know has some sewing skills you could do yourself.  Maybe a combo of both would do the trick! Best of luck.

Report Inappropriate Content

Re: diabetes, football and omnipod

‎07-16-2013 09:50 PM

When my son played 6th grade football last year, we had to change the pod every day that they were "hitting."  He was on the line, and the hittling would dislodge the cannula.  He wore it on his arm instead of the leg, and we put in the minium amount of insulin.  They only had football 4 days a week for 6 weeks.  We did not go to shots.  He suspended the insulin for practices with lots of activity.
